questions.question_text:
You have an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) load balancer distributing traffic via an evenly-weighted round robin policy to your back-end web servers. You notice that one of your web servers is receiving more traffic than other web servers.
How can you resolve this to make sure traffic is evenly distributed across all back-end webservers?

discussion.content:
A is correct.
Session persistence is a method to direct all requests originating from a single logical client to a single backend web server. You enable session persistence when you create a load balancer or when you create a backend set. You can also edit an existing backend set to enable, disable, or change the session persistence configuration.
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Balance/Reference/sessionpersistence.htm
The listener is defined per traffic type, not per individual backend server.
are these questions valied for 1z0-1072-21 exam???

Selected Answer: D
D is corrent answer.
https://community.oracle.com/customerconnect/discussion/536535/in-oci-load-balancer-can-not-distribute-traffic-evently-to-the-backend-web-servers

Disable cookie-based session persistence on your backend set: Cookie-based session persistence is a mechanism used by the load balancer to maintain session affinity for requests being sent to the backend set. When cookie-based session persistence is enabled, the load balancer ensures that a client's request is always sent to the same backend server that it initially connected to. Disabling cookie-based session persistence can help balance the load across all backend servers, but it can also cause issues if the backend servers require session affinity. In this case, disabling cookie-based session persistence may not be the best solution. Solution is D

Selected Answer: A
Since they mentioned that one server is getting more load which is possible when session persistence is enabled as this will impose session affinity.

Selected Answer: A
Persistent cookies can imbalance the algorithm

Selected Answer: A

A

discussion.content:
not sure about A as the right answer. 
To handle TCP, HTTP, and HTTPS traffic, you must configure at least one listener per traffic type. 
Therefore you can't create one listener for all traffic types. You have to create a separate one for each traffic type. 
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Balance/Tasks/managinglisteners.htm

comments.content: Traffic is already distributed to backend servers as the question is stated, so that is not correct, the correct answer is A

Not exactly . 
To handle TCP, HTTP, and HTTPS traffic, you must configure at least one listener per traffic type.
Therefore you can't create one listener for all traffic types. You have to create a separate one for each traffic type.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Balance/Tasks/managinglisteners.htm

discussion.content:
Agreed, A is correct.

Create one listener for traffic type: TCP, HTTP, and HTTPS.
In addition, listeners are attached to back-end sets and not back-end servers.

Just finished reviewing chapter 2 - connectivity and I agree with the rest of the guys, A is the correct answer. Creating separate listeners means assigning different ports to the servers, you wouldn't have any control of the incoming traffic in any of the ports.
A is correct

choices.C: Disable SSL configuration associated with your backend set.
choices.D: Create separate listeners for each backend web server.
choices.A: Disable cookie-based session persistence on your backend set.
choices.B: Change keep-alive setting between the load balancer and backend server.

questions.question_text:
A financial firm is designing an application architecture for its online trading platform that must have high availability and fault tolerance.
Their solutions architect configured the application to use an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Object Storage bucket located in the US West (us-phoenix-1) region to store large amounts of financial data. The stored financial data in the bucket must not be affected even if there is an outage in one of the Availability Domains or a complete region.
What should the architect do to avoid any costly service disruptions and ensure data durability?

choices.C: Copy the Object Storage bucket to a block volume.
choices.A: Create a new Object Storage bucket in another region and configure lifecycle policy to move data every 5 days.
choices.D: Create a replication policy to send data to a different bucket in another OCI region.
choices.B: Create a lifecycle policy to regularly send data from Standard to Archive storage.

discussion.content:
Replication provides protection from regional outages https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingreplication.htm
So it's D
D is correct
D is correct
D should be the correct option.

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct answer.
The answer cannot be A, what guarantees do we have that no outages within the 5 days?
D is the one

Selected Answer: D
Replication provides protection from regional outages, aids in disaster recovery efforts, and addresses data redundancy compliance requirements. Maintaining multiple copies of data in regional locations closer to user access can also reduce latency.
i think B is the answer because as you can see "its avoiding costly" so isnt it sounds the archive storage is referring to?

comments.content: No offense, but it's "to avoid any costly service disruptions". It's not about the budget as I understand.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is right

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
Its D, logic since no mention about timline 5days or fixed logic timeline

In approach to prevent disruption is to create a data replication, which is required to of the admin to create a replication policy to synchronize data file to another region. 
Therefore the correct answer is D
D is correct
D is correct
D is correct
It's an online trading platform so the data must be always available. The solution is D
I second that, since the 5 day wait period is not relevant to the question.

I guess it is D:
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingreplication.htm

questions.question_text: In Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Container Engine for Kubernetes (OKE), what does a Replica Set do?

discussion.content: it should be B. It maintains a stable set of replica Pods running at any given time.

B is the correct answer. It maintains a stable set of replica Pods running at any given time
https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/controllers/replicaset/

Selected Answer: B
B is Correct
https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/controllers/replicaset/
A ReplicaSet's purpose is to maintain a stable set of replica Pods running at any given time. As such, it is often used to guarantee the availability of a specified number of identical Pods.

Selected Answer: B

questions.question_text:
As a solution architect, you are showcasing the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Object Storage feature about Object Versioning to a customer.
Which statement is true in regards to OCI Object Storage Versioning?

discussion.content: B is correct

B is correct

Understanding Object Versioning Status
Each Object Storage bucket has object versioning status of disabled, enabled, or suspended. By default, object versioning is disabled on a bucket. It's important to understand the behavior associated with each object versioning status.

Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingversioning.htm

Question is wrong - Add "Not"
A,B,C in favour of object versioning
D Not in favour of Object versioning

Selected Answer: B
disabled by default B
A, B and C are correct as per documentation. I think they have missed 'NOT' in the question. If it is which statement is not true, then Answer is D.
But who answers the questions, 90% of proposed answers are wrong ^^

Selected Answer: B
According to the given link, It should be answer B
this is oracle error as there are 3 correct answers A,B,C. it supposedly multi answer case

Ref: https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Object/Tasks/usingversioning.htm
Answer is B as by default versioning is disabled we need to enable it

questions.question_text:
You created a public subnet and an internet gateway in your virtual cloud network (VCN) of Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. The public subnet has an associated route table and security list. However, after creating several compute instances in the public subnet, none can reach the Internet.
Which two are possible reasons for the connectivity issue? (Choose two.)

choices.E: A NAT gateway is needed to enable the communication flow to internet.
choices.C: There is no dynamic routing gateway (DRG) associated with the VCN.
choices.B: There is no stateful egress rule in the security list associated with the public subnet.
choices.D: There is no stateful ingress rule in the security list associated with the public subnet.
choices.A: The route table has no default route for routing traffic to the internet gateway.

discussion.content: AB correct

A B are correct. REF:

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Concepts/securitylists.htm#Default
"Stateful egress: Allow all traffic. This allows instances to initiate traffic of any kind to any destination. Notice that this means the instances with public IP addresses can talk to any internet IP address if the VCN has a configured internet gateway. And because stateful security rules use connection tracking, the response traffic is automatically allowed regardless of any ingress rules. For more information, see Stateful Versus Stateless Rules."

If the instance cannot reach internet, it means that its default SL doesn't have a stateful egress rule (Even though default security lists arrive with default stateful egress rule enabling All traffic for all ports rule).

A,B is true. no route table= nothing
no ingress= internet cant see internal IP
no egress= cant see internet
DRG and Nat is not necessary

Selected Answer: AB
You need to reach the internet, and its a public subnet.
If it was a private subnet you would configure a NAT gateway.
correct .. AB
Answer is AB

A & B 
Since Statefulness means if Egress is configured, Ingres would be automatically configured as well, Egress goes our to the internet, hence A,B is correct.

comments.content: I've tried in LAB. If you create an instance within a Public Subnet and Internet Gateway, only when you delete the default stateful Egress rules, the internet navigation stop. If you rty to delete all the default stateful Ingress rules the web surfing is done in any case. So the answer is AB, dude!

discussion.content: AD. Ingress to define in which port connections from the outside are allowed.

A and B correct 
Stateful egress: Allow all traffic. This allows instances to initiate traffic of any kind to any destination. Notice that this means the instances with public IP addresses can talk to any internet IP address if the VCN has a configured internet gateway. And because stateful security rules use connection tracking, the response traffic is automatically allowed regardless of any ingress rules. For more information, see Stateful Versus Stateless Rules.
A+B will allow instances to go put to the internet, but we need D to get to them from internet. I vote A+D

It's definively A, D. There is no nedd of egress rules, as they are already defined in the default SL for any IP and port:
"If you've configured the public subnet to use the default security list, remember that the list includes several helpful default rules that enable basic required access (examples: ingress SSH, egress access to all destinations)."
I belive it's A and B
answer is A nd B , because instances unable to reach internet that means egress need to be enabled
Ingress is when someone make a request for your CLOUD VM's, and this is not the case, as the VM's want's to access the internet, so A and B.

Stateful Rules
Marking a security rule as stateful indicates that you want to use connection tracking for any traffic that matches that rule. This means that when an instance receives traffic matching the stateful ingress rule, the response is tracked and automatically allowed back to the originating host, regardless of any egress rules applicable to the instance.
So it's A D No egress rule is needed when you define ingress rule

A,B are the correct answers. 
-DRG is used when you want to create a path between your network and destinations other than the internet, for example your on-prem network.
-Stateful ingress rules are automatically created.
-Nat gateway would be used if the created network was private.

comments.content: + Nat gateway would be used if the traffic was originated from the internet

discussion.content:
AB
The servers need a stateful egress rule for reaching the internet.
sorry A,D correct

If you rty to delete all the default stateful Ingress rules the web surfing is done in any case. So the answer is AB, dude!
